Description: Body sherd of Attic large black-figured pottery cup, possibly a band-cup; interior: glazed black; exterior: black figure decoration consisting of part of four horse team (with added white dots on reins, dot rosettes on collar, and added red on hindquarters) galloping to right; behind the rear of the horses, warrior striding left, body frontal and right arm raised; red on helmet, white dots on corselet at neck, armhole, and waist); below team, legs of fallen warrior (red on greaves, with white dots at edge, white dots at bottom of chiton); part of a round shield (on rim, two rows of white dots with semi-circles between); parts of other figures on far side of team and at their heads, where there is puzzling complex incision, perhaps fire/thunderbolt of Zeus.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The scene is very likely a Gigantomachy.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0489) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
